body_text.text: The decay Zc(3900) ± → ωπ ± is searched for using data samples collected with the BESIII detector operating at the BEPCII storage ring at center-of-mass energies √ s = 4.23 and 4.26 GeV.
No significant signal for the Zc(3900) ± is found, and upper limits at the 90% confidence level on the Born cross section for the process e + e − → Zc(3900) ± π ∓ → ωπ + π − are determined to be 0.
I. INTRODUCTION
Recently, in the study of e + e − → J/ψπ + π − , a distinct charged structure, named the Z c (3900) ± , was observed in the J/ψπ ± spectrum by BESIII [1] and Belle [2].
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Its existence was confirmed shortly thereafter with CLEO-c data [3].
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: The existence of the neutral partner in the decay Z c (3900) 0 → J/ψπ 0 has also been reported in CLEO-c data [3] and by BESIII [4].
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: The Z c (3900) is a good candidate for an exotic state beyond simple quark models, since it contains a cc pair and is also electrically charged.
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Noting that the Z c (3900) has a mass very close to the D * D threshold (3875 MeV), BESIII analyzed the process e + e − → π ± (DD * ) ∓ , and a clear structure in the (DD * ) ∓ mass spectrum is seen, called the Z c (3885).
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: The measured mass and width are (3883.9±1.5±4.2) MeV/c 2 and (24.8 ± 3.3 ± 11.0) MeV, respectively, and quantum numbers J P = 1 + are favored [5].
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Assuming the Z c (3885) → DD * and the Z c (3900) → J/ψπ signals are from the same source, the ratio of partial widths Γ(Zc(3885)→DD * ) Γ(Zc(3900)→J/ψπ) is determined to be 6.
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: The observation of the Z c (3900) has stimulated many theoretical studies of its nature.
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Possible interpretations are tetra-quark [6], hadro-charmonium [7], D * D molecule [8] and threshold effects [9][10][11].
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Lattice QCD studies provide theoretical support for the existence of X(3872) [12] but not for the Z c (3900) [13][14][15][16][17].
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: However, those studies were carried out on small volumes with unphysically heavy up and down quarks.
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: It is also worth noting that no resonant structure in J/ψπ is observed in B 0 → J/ψπ + π − by LHCb [18], in B 0 → J/ψK − π + by Belle [19] or in γp → J/ψπ + n by COMPASS [20].
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: The decay properties of a state can provide useful information on its internal structure.
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: There are three important decay modes for charmonium-like states:
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: (i) "fallapart" decays to open charm mesons;
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: (ii) cascades to hidden charm mesons; and
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: (iii) decays to light hadrons via intermediate gluons.
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: In addition, as shown in Ref.
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: [9,10], an enhancement near the DD * threshold can be produced via rescattering of hidden or open charm final states.
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Decays of the Z c (3900) to light hadrons can play a unique role in distinguishing a resonance from threshold effects, because the decay mode with cc annihilation involves neither hidden nor open charm final states.
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: However, theory estimates of annihilation widths to light hadrons are only order of magnitude due to uncertainties of wave function effects and QCD corrections [21,22].
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: A sizeable Z c (3900) decay width to light hadrons might be expected in analogy to η c or χ cJ into hadronic final states.
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Among a large number of hadronic final states that are available for a I G (J P ) = 1 + (1 + ) resonance decay, ωπ is one of the typical decay modes which are not suppressed by any known selection rule.
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: In this paper, we report a search for Z c (3900) ± → ωπ ± based on e + e − annihilation samples taken at center-of-mass (CM) energies √ s = 4.23 and 4.26 GeV around the peak of Y (4260).
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: The data samples were collected with the BESIII [23] detector operating at the BEPCII storage ring.
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: The integrated luminosity of these data samples are measured by analyzing the large-angle Bhabha scattering events with an uncertainty of 1.0% [24] and are equal to 1092 pb −1 and 826 pb −1 , for √ s = 4.23 and 4.26 GeV, respectively.

BESIII EXPERIMENT AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION
The BESIII detector, described in detail in Ref.
body_text.section: II. BESIII EXPERIMENT AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: [23], has a geometrical acceptance of 93% of 4π.
body_text.section: II. BESIII EXPERIMENT AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: A smallcell helium-based main drift chamber (MDC) provides a charged particle momentum resolution of 0.5% at 1 GeV/c in a 1 T magnetic field, and supplies energyloss (dE/dx) measurements with a resolution of 6% for minimum-ionizing pions.
body_text.section: II. BESIII EXPERIMENT AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: The electromagnetic calorimeter (EMC) measures photon energies with a resolution of 2.5% (5%) at 1.0 GeV in the barrel (end-caps).
body_text.section: II. BESIII EXPERIMENT AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: Particle identification (PID) is provided by a time-of-flight system (TOF) with a time resolution of 80 ps (110 ps) for the barrel (end-caps).
body_text.section: II. BESIII EXPERIMENT AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: The muon system, located in the iron flux return yoke of the magnet, provides 2 cm position resolution and detects muon tracks with momenta greater than 0.5 GeV/c.
body_text.section: II. BESIII EXPERIMENT AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: The geant4-based [25] Monte Carlo (MC) simulation software boost [26] includes the geometric description of the BESIII detector and a simulation of the detector response.
body_text.section: II. BESIII EXPERIMENT AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: It is used to optimize event selection criteria, estimate backgrounds and evaluate the detection efficiency.
body_text.section: II. BESIII EXPERIMENT AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: We generate signal MC samples of e + e − → Z c (3900) ± π ∓ → ωπ + π − uniformly in phase space, where the ω decays to π + π − π 0 .
body_text.section: II. BESIII EXPERIMENT AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: The decays of ω → π + π − π 0 are generated with the OMEGA DALITZ model in evtgen [27,28].
body_text.section: II. BESIII EXPERIMENT AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: Initial state radiation (ISR) is simulated with kkmc [29,30], where the Born cross section of e + e − → Z c (3900) ± π ∓ is assumed to follow a Y (4260) Breit-Wigner (BW) line shape with resonance parameters taken from the Particle Data Group (PDG) [31], in which listed as X(4260).
body_text.section: II. BESIII EXPERIMENT AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: Final state radiation (FSR) effects associated with charged particles are handled with PHOTOS [29].
body_text.section: II. BESIII EXPERIMENT AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: For studies of possible backgrounds, inclusive Y (4260) MC samples with luminosity equivalent to the experimental data at √ s = 4.23 and √ s = 4.26 GeV are generated, where the main known decay channels are generated using evtgen [27,28] with branching fractions taken from the PDG [31].
body_text.section: II. BESIII EXPERIMENT AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: The remaining events associated with charmonium decays are generated with lundcharm [32], while continuum hadronic events are generated with PYTHIA [33].
body_text.section: II. BESIII EXPERIMENT AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: QED processes such as Bhabha scattering, dimuon and digamma events are generated with kkmc [29,30].
